ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Sheets
ygData.msgSnippet: Thought I would join the conversation because we have some of the same concerns about getting rid of the order.xml file as Erik does. Some of our concerns may

Thought I would join the conversation because we have some of the same
conc=
erns about getting rid of the order.xml file as Erik does. Some of
our conc=
erns may come from not knowing enough yet about the new sheets
way of confi=
guring jobs.

We think that the crawl configuration is important enough to =
deposit
into our preservation repository along with its associated harvest =
so
we have recently developed a mets profile for web harvests that embeds
t=
he order.xml within it. We also have a lot of related code, etc.
built to c=
reate and work with these.  The existing schema for the
order.xml works wel=
l enough for our needs to be able to validate the
order.xml file. With the =
sheets way of configuration is there a way to
serialize the configuration t=
o a file? And can we generate the
configuration without using the web inter=
face? When you are embedding
content into a mets file the XML format is eas=
iest but if the sheets
can be serialized to some format we could find a way=
 to include or
point to it.

My other concern with heritrix 2.0 is that hcc=
 is incompatible with
it. How incompatible? Is this just in the short-term =
or is  hcc being
phased out?

thanks,
Andrea

On Dec 12, 2007 2:25 PM, Erik=
 Hetzner <erik.hetzner@...> wrote:
> Hi Paul.
>
> Thanks again for the=
 answers to my questions. A few responses are
> inline below.
>
> At Tue, 1=
1 Dec 2007 17:58:57 -0800,
> Paul Jack <pjack@...> wrote:
> >
> > >=
 Is it possible to explain the rationale for leaving order.xml
> > > files =
behind? I know that we have some investment in the format,
> > > and though=
 we can of course move forward it is not clear to me
> > > from looking at =
the sheets.
> >
> > There were a number of reasons:
> >
> > 1. The XML wasn=
't well-defined for most modules, so the benefits of
> > XML were mostly lo=
st. Eg, it would be nice to have
> >
> > <FetchDNS>
> > <accept-non-dns-res=
olves>false</accept-non-dns-resolves>
> > <deciderules/>
> > <digest-algori=
thm>SHA1</digest-algorithm>
> > <digest-content>true</digest-content>
> > <=
enabled>true</enabled>
> > </FetchDNS>
> >
> > ...so that configuration she=
ets could be validated using standard
> > XML tools. But that would also be=
 a huge departure from the existing
> > order.xml, would require more infra=
structure, and would make it more
> > difficult to support third-party modu=
les.
>
> While I agree that the order.xml format what a bit funny looking, =
I've
> just spent a bit of time convincing myself that a pretty reasonable
=
> schema could have been written to validate the order.xml format with
> re=
lax ng.
>
> > 2. XML's nesting provides a good visual sense of structure fo=
r the
> > old order.xml and for the new global sheet, but didn't work so we=
ll
> > for override sheets, which typically contain only a few settings.
> =
> We'd either have to nest many levels of empty tags to get to the
> > actu=
al overrides, or have two different XML formats for the global
> > sheet an=
d override sheets.
>
> This makes a lot of sense.
>
> > 3. The one-setting-=
per-line format plays well with command-line tools
> > such as diff.
>
> Al=
so makes sense.
>
> > 4. The one-setting-per-line format closely resembles =
the new JMX API
> > for modifying sheets. In particular, code used for JMX =
transport of
> > settings is re-used to read/write the sheet files.
>
> Aha=
. This makes even more sense.
>
> Thanks for your detailed answers. If I se=
em reluctant to leave behind
> the order.xml format, it is not for a partic=
ular love of xml or the
> order.xml format. It is simply that we have infra=
structure deployed
> that makes use of order.xml. Additionally, I have been=
 developing an
> HTTP interface for Heritrix which extends the order.xml fo=
rmat to
> allow creating jobs, retrieving data, etc. from a running Heritri=
x
> instance using HTTP (rather than JMX), and I am going to have to
> dete=
rmine how to rework this to work with the new settings format. I
> had not =
realized until a few days ago that the new settings had
> progressed so far=
 and that order.xml files were to be left behind.
>
> > [=85]
> > The secon=
d one is not an empty string; it's saying "Create a new list
> > that will =
only contain String values." To add an elements to the list
> > you'd use:
=
> >
> > root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:0=3Dstring, audio/*;=

> > q=3D0.2, audio/basic
> > root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-header=
s:1=3Dstring, text/*, text/
> > html, text/html;level=3D1
>
> Ok, so a dist=
inction is made between primitives and objects,
> basically.
>
> Since the =
order of the lines matters for maps, can you do something to
> append to a =
list? For instance:
>
> root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:_=3D=
string, audio/*; q=3D0.2, audio/basic
>
> Just a though, since I generally =
dislike hard coding the index of a
> list.
>
> > > Why is the config.txt fi=
le necessary?
> >
> > It bootstraps the settings system. Since the settings=
 system itself
> > uses a BDB, we needed a place to put the configuration f=
or BDB.
>
> Make sense, thanks.
>
> > > Can one define any settings in it?
=
> >
> > No; the contents of config.txt are predefined. The valid properties=

> > are all listed in the file; anything not listed is simply ignored.
>
>=
 Ok. Thanks.
>
> > > What is the difference between 'primary, org.archive[.=
..]' and
> > > 'object, org.archive[...]'?
> >
> > Each class of object can=
 have one "primary" object nominated in the
> > global sheet. If a setting =
uses the "primary" tag then the object
> > created is registered as the pri=
mary.
> >
> > Primary objects are automatically selected as the default val=
ue for
> > most module settings. For instance, FetchHTTP has a server-cache=

> > setting for specifying the ServerCache to use with FetchHTTP. The
> > =
default value for that setting is to use the "primary" ServerCache.
> > In =
this way only one ServerCache instance needs to be specified in
> > the she=
et, and all the modules that need it just find it.
>
> I had assumed (corre=
ctly, I think) that in the past the names of
> certain objects determined t=
heir primary-ness (for instance, the
> object named 'scope' was the scope u=
sed for the crawl). This seems to
> make more sense than enforcing a partic=
ular name for the settings.
>
>
> best,
> Erik Hetzner
> ;; Erik Hetzner, C=
alifornia Digital Library
> ;; gnupg key id: 1024D/01DB07E3
>
